typeData.textContent:
Introduction to Week 5

Welcome to the fifth week of the course! The video in this section details what you can expect from this part of the course.

Assigned Readings
You should carefully read the assigned readings for this part of the course (i.e., OpenStax Psychology text: Chapter 10, Introduction and Chapter 10, sections 10.1 to 10.3) before proceeding on with this part of the course. You will have a chance to check your understanding of the readings.

It's important to note that not all of the material that is in the text is in the video lectures, and vice versa. So, it's important to keep up with both.

nodes.title: Connections with Motivation and Freud's Psychoanalytic Theory (Coby Zamoranos)
nodes.description: A reflection on how Freud's Id, Ego, and Superego, suggests that our motivations comes from different internal perspectives

typeData.textContent:
A reflection on how Freud's Id, Ego, and Superego, suggests that our motivations comes from different internal perspectives
Id: (Instincts) Similar to the James-Lange theory, the Id suggests that decisions are purely  based on physiological and biological needs. This come as a foil to the Superego.  

Superego (Morals)- As the Superego is based around the idea of conscience and morality, this suggests that parts of motivation comes from moralistic goals eg. guilt. The superego influences the Idâ€™s impulses

Ego (reality, self control) - the Ego is known and the mediator between the above two. With its ties to reality and realistic solutions, the ego can manipulate motivation to keep it grounded, thus self-control

Gender Identity: Trans* and Intersex Identities (Samantha Banfield)

typeData.textContent:
One of the areas explored in Section 10.3 of Spielmanâ€™s â€˜Psychologyâ€™ is gender identity and dysphoria (2017). This past month, there has been much attention on renowned author J.K. Rowling and her tweets (and subsequent statements) about the trans community. What sparked the recent public backlash was when Rowling responded to a Devex opinion piece on Twitter about creating a more equal post COVID-19 world for people who menstruate. â€œPeople who menstruate. Iâ€™m sure there used to be a word for those people. Someone help me out. Wumben? Wimpund? Woomud?â€ (@jk_rowling, 2020). Rowling has been criticized before for speaking up on Twitter against a UK woman being fired over transphobic comments, and has stated she refuses to bow to down to a movement that she believes is doing â€œdemonstrable harm in seeking to erode â€˜womanâ€™ as a political and biological class and offering cover to predators like few before itâ€ (Associated Press, 2020).

There is lots to unpack here. Rowlingâ€™s tweet implies that all women menstruate, but what about those who donâ€™t? Gender identity refers to oneâ€™s sense of being male or female, Spielman writes in the course text (2017). This identity may or may not align with oneâ€™s sex assigned at birth. Some individuals do not identify with the gender that aligns with their biological sex and experience gender dysphoria (Spielman, 2017, p. 347). People who experience gender dysphoria often identify as transgender or trans. Some trans individuals may decide to undergo hormone therapy or gender reassignment surgeries to help their physical appearance match their gender identity, but how one decides to present or perform their gender is unique, and should not be forced into a socially constructed box.

Rowlingâ€™s words not only harmful to the trans community, but the intersex community as well. Intersex and trans communities share similarities in that they are both marginalized due to the ideology of binary sex and gender (Costello 2016, p. 83). Intersex is often conflated with ambiguous genitalia that cannot be described as entirely female or entirely male (Horlacher 2016, p.8). Other attributes, such as XXY sex chromosomes, are not visible outside the body. In th TED Talk â€˜The way we think about biological sex is wrong,â€™ Emily Quinn talks about her lived experience of being intersex. Quinn was born with XY chromosomes, a vagina, and balls inside her body. Quinn was also born without a uterus, meaning she does not menstruate and cannot have biological children. Would Rowling say she is not a woman?

Intersex and Trans studies raise the question of what kind of body one needs to have in order to claim membership to a particular gender (Horlacher 2016, p. 9). â€œDo you have to have a uterus to be a woman?â€ Emily Quinn asks, â€œThereâ€™s a lot of us who are born without oneâ€ (2019, 4:18) Intersex identities show that biological sex is not always black or white. â€œWe constantly change and evolve, the more we understand as a society,â€ says Quinn. â€œNobody actually fits in a boxâ€ (2019, 13:31).  

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Associated Press. â€œâ€™Harry Potterâ€™ Creator J.K. Rowling Says She Refuses to â€˜Bow downâ€™ to Criticism about Her Recent Comments on Transgender People.â€ MarketWatch, MarketWatch, 11 June 2020, www.marketwatch.com/story/harry-potter-creator-jk-rowling-says-she-refuses-to-bow-down-to-criticism-about-her-recent-comments-on-transgender-people-2020-06-11

Costello C.G. (2016) Intersex and Trans* Communities: Commonalities and Tensions. In: Horlacher S. (eds) Transgender and Intersex: Theoretical, Practical, and Artistic Perspectives. Palgrave Macmillan, New York

Horlacher S. (2016) Transgender and Intersex: Theoretical, Practical, and Artistic Perspectives. In: Horlacher S. (eds) Transgender and Intersex: Theoretical, Practical, and Artistic Perspectives. Palgrave Macmillan, New York

Rowling, JK (@jk_rowling). â€œPeople who menstruate. Iâ€™m sure there used to be a word for those people. Someone help me out. Wumben? Wimpund? Woomud?â€ June 6, 2020, 2:35p.m. Tweet. Retrieved from https://twitter.com/jk_rowling/status/1269382518362509313

Spielman, R. M. (2017). Psychology. Houston, Texas 77005: OpenStax.

TED (2019, March 6). The way we think about biological sex is wrong | Emily Quinn [Video file]. Retrieved from https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=stUl_OapUso&t=169s

Love is something most people seek throughout a lifetime, however what love looks like has constantly been debated through time and discussed by academics and artists alike. In order to achieve a healthy relationship, certain aspects about the concept of love must be understood. Looking throughout literature, the theme of love is very prevalent, often exemplified in famous poems such as Sonnet 18 by William Shakespeare or A Valediction: Forbidden Mourning by John Donne, and even plays such as Romeo and Juliet by Shakespeare. Each work observes and discusses a different aspect of love.

According to Sternberg, there are seven different types of love, each with certain areas of human connection fulfilled and certain areas missing. His theory assumes that a relationship is more stable with a greater number of components, that love will change over the course of a relationship, and that most forms of love are impure mixes. The first form is liking, which is intimacy only, in which a close friendship exists but lacks passion or commitment. The second form is infatuation, which lacks intimacy and commitment and is lust. Empty love is when there only exists commitment but no passion or intimacy; when there is both passion and intimacy but no commitment that is called romantic love, passion and commitment without intimacy is called fatuous love, and intimacy and commitment without passion is called companionate love. Consummate love is the complete form of love according to this theory, where there exist all three components.  
Examples of some of these types of love can be found in the above mentioned literature. In Romeo and Juliet, the connection between the two lovers is infatuation, where there is only passion. There is no intimacy since they do not know each other before falling in love, and no commitment. In Sonnet 18, the speaker compares their love to a summerâ€™s day, calling them even â€œmore lovelyâ€ (Shakespeare, 2) than a summerâ€™s day. This demonstrates the existence of passion in their love, and the commitment can be seen through how the speaker discusses how â€œevery fair from fair sometime declinesâ€ (Shakespeare, 7) yet to them, â€œ[their loverâ€™s] eternal summer shall not fadeâ€ (Shakespeare, 9) and they will remain â€œso long as men can breathe or eyes can seeâ€ (Shakespeare, 13). As such, the connection that they have can be defined according to Sternbergâ€™s theory as fatuous love.

 On the other hand, romantic love can be seen in A Valediction: Forbidden Mourning as the speaker describes that â€œ[their] two souls are oneâ€ (Donne, 21), exemplifying their intimacy. Furthermore, â€œprofanation of [their] joys tell the laity [of their] loveâ€ (Donne, 7-8) showing the passion the speaker has for their love as they describe various metaphors detailing their connection. Evidently, the concept of love has been represented and described in many different ways throughout history.

nodes.title: Physiological Mechanism of Sexual Behavior and Motivation (Fadwa Bouziane)
The Genetics of Sexuality (Lang Kuoch)
nodes.description: A deeper look into the research over the past decades on the biological markers of human sexual orientation.

typeData.textContent:
In an era where outdated laws and backwards mindsets on sexual orientation still persists in societies and cultures worldwide, people have turned to the name of science to help uncover some of the truth. While for many of us the answer seems obvious; that sexuality is an innate, stable, generally unchanging part of who we are, some are still deeply entrenched in a mindset that it is a voluntary affliction of lifestyle choices. Desperate in our attempts to dissuade these hurtful and bigoted theories, we have found unlikely allies in the geneticists and neurologists, who have over the past decades discovered some interesting insights on the genetics of our sexuality. Specifically, it appears that sexual orientation, particular in that of males, has some significant basis in our biologyâ€”even before we are born.

The hunt for the elusive â€œgay geneâ€ has been difficult, and since 1993, when geneticist Dean Hamer first linked male homosexuality to a section of the X chromosome (Hamer et al., 1993), we have made some significant breakthroughs in the field. Firstly, it has become more and more obvious that finding a single gene that codes for sexual orientation is highly unlikelyâ€”rather it is more probable that a collection of genes interacting with each other is responsible for the difference. Genome-wide association studies have found that the size of diencephalon, a region in the brain with the active gene SLITRK6, consistently differs in size between individuals who are homosexual or heterosexual (Sanders et al., 2017). Further, family studies, twin studies, and segregation studies have all concluded that there is some heritability in male homosexuality; that is, when one set of a twin identifies as gay, it is also more likely that his twin will have the same sexual orientation. Interestingly, however, it seems that this link is not reported for females.
While this furthers our understanding, it also increases the complexity of our understanding of human sexual orientation at the same time. Although significant biological factors have been discovered linking to male homosexuality, not much has been found for female casesâ€”and yet, female homosexuality is prevalent in at least 1% of the female population in North America. So, what does the mean?

Well, for the future of our research into the biological side of things, it may mean that we still need to be on the lookout for other genotypic factors that come into play for human sexuality, especially that of female homosexuality. This also begs another question: if it is indeed biological (which now it seems it is), what could be the evolutionary advantage of it? Why has natural selection favoured a steady population of homosexual individuals (estimated to be around 2%-6% of the population) hundreds of years down our evolutionary line?

While theories have hypothesized that it may have something to do with having extra helpers around to care for our young (Vasey & VanderLaan, 2010), we need to remember that sexual behaviour is vastly diverse and complex. While there is no singular â€œgay geneâ€ to be found, the overwhelming scientific evidence suggest there is a basis in our biology and pre-natal conditions, factors that we could never voluntarily choose for ourselves.

References

Alan R. Sanders, G. W. (2017). Genome-Wide Association Study of Male Sexual Orientation. Scientific Reports. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-017-15736-4

Andrea Ganna, K. J. (2019). Large-scale GWAS reveals insights into the genetic architecture of same-sex sexual behavior. Science. DOI: 10.1126/science.aat7693

Brian S. Mustanski, M. G. (2005). A genomewide scan of male sexual orientation. Human Genetics. DOI 10.1007/s00439-004-1241-4

Dean H. Hamer, S. H. (1993). A linkage between DNA markers on the X chromosome and male sexual orientation. Science, 321-327. DOI: 10.1126/science.8332896

Paul L. Vasey, D. P. (2010). An Adaptive Cognitive Dissociation Between Willingness to Help Kin and Nonkin in Samoan Faâ€™afafine. Sage Journals. https://doi.org/10.1177/0956797609359623

In honour of Pride Month.

nodes.title: Eating Disorders - Lukas Franz
nodes.description:
A short overview of eating disorders
This node is not supposed to be connected to the obesity epidemic node. (We are unable to delete this node to change the connections)

typeData.textContent:
Anorexia Nervosa, Bulimia Nervosa, binge eating, and many other eating disorders all stem from psychiatric illnesses (Klump et al., 2009). These three are the most commonly seen eating disorders and they can be caused by a variety of factors, usually some combination of sociocultural, psychological, and biological (Culbert et al., 2015). These factors can manifest in many different ways; for example, a sociocultural factor could be the way that media glorifies being thin which could pressure people into starving or purging themselves (Anorexia Nervosa and Bulimia Nervosa respectively). A psychological factor could be a simple personality trait such as impulsivity causing one to gorge on more food than they reasonably should. Finally, a biological factor could be the link between dopamine level disturbances in patients with AN or BN which is not yet fully understood (Culbert et al., 2015).

From a psychological perspective, eating disorders can often come as a side effect of some mental illnesses. A 2003 study has linked them to obsessive-compulsive personality traits (Anderluh et al., 2003); other studies have linked eating disorders to Anxiety  (Kaye and Oberndorfer, 2010), parental figures with mental illness (Bould et al. 2014), and the list just continues. Given these connections, it is clear that eating disorders are not just a physiological disorder but also a psychological one as well.


Works cited
Bould, H., Koupil, I., Dalman, C., Destavola, B., Lewis, G., & Magnusson, C. (2014). Parental mental illness and eating disorders in offspring. International Journal of Eating Disorders, 48(4), 383â€“391. doi: 10.1002/eat.22325

Culbert, K., Racine, S., & Klump, K. (2015). Research Review: What we have learned about the causes of eating disorders - a synthesis of sociocultural, psychological, and biological research. Journal Of Child Psychology And Psychiatry, 56(11), 1141-1164. doi: 10.1111/jcpp.12441

Kaye, W., & Oberndorfer, T. (2010). Appetitive Regulation in Anorexia Nervosa and Bulimia Nervosa. The Oxford Handbook of Eating Disorders, 73â€“102. doi: 10.1093/oxfordhb/9780195373622.013.0006

Klump, K. L., Bulik, C. M., Kaye, W. H., Treasure, J., & Tyson, E. (2009). Academy for eating disorders position paper: eating disorders are serious mental illnesses. The International journal of eating disorders, 42(2), 97â€“103. https://doi.org/10.1002/eat.20589

Anderluh, M. B., Tchanturia, K., Rabe-Hesketh, S., & Treasure, J. (2003). Childhood Obsessive-Compulsive Personality Traits in Adult Women With Eating Disorders: Defining a Broader Eating Disorder Phenotype. American Journal of Psychiatry, 160(2), 242â€“247. doi: 10.1176/appi.ajp.160.2.242

nodes.title: Risk Factors for Eating Disorders (Teresa Liao)

typeData.textContent:
Eating disorders are mental illnesses recognised by the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5). These conditions are complex and are still being studied today. Researchers generally agree that eating disorders arises from some combination of biological, psychological, and socio-cultural factors. Anyone can develop an eating disorder but having more risk factors increases a personâ€™s likelihood of developing an eating disorder.


Biological Factors

-Family History of Eating Disorders (Bulik, Sullivan, & Kendler, 2003; Strober, 2000).

-Type 1 Diabetes (Jones et. al., 2000).

Eating disorders in diabetic subjects are associated with the omission of insulin. Initiation of insulin treatment is often accompanied by weight gain.


Psychological Factors

-Childhood Obsessive Compulsive Personality Traits.

These traits include perfectionism, inflexibility, excessive doubt and cautiousness, and drive for order and symmetry (Anderluh et. al., 2003).

-Traumatic Experiences.

These can include but are not limited to physical, sexual, and/or emotional abuse, neglect, and victimization. From research data, basically â€œany experience that can produce PTSD, partial PTSD, or any form of clinically significant anxietyâ€ (Brewerton, 2007, p. 287).

-Depression and Anxiety.

There are studies that support that eating disorders are sequela of depression and anxiety disorders, but it is also likely that depression, anxiety, and eating disorders share some etiological factors (Brownell, & Walsh, 2018).

-High Neurotic Personality and Low Self-Esteem (Cervera et al., 2003).

Neuroticism is a personality trait that consist of the tendency be in negative or anxious emotional state. People with neurotic personality also tend be in more depressive mood.


Socio-Cultural Factors

-Media Portrayal of Ideal Body (Lawrie, Sullivan, Davies, & Hill, 2006).

-Participation in Sports that Emphasis Body Shape or Leanness (Durme, Goossens, & Braet, 2012; Kong & Harris, 2014).

-Teasing or Bullying.

-Abusive Environment.


Other Factors

-Having Parents with Bipolar Affective Disorder, Personality Disorder, Anxiety, or Depression. 

Research shows that there is a correlation between parents with mental illnesses and their offspring developing eating disorders, but it is still unclear whether the eating disorder arises from genetics or the environment or a combination of both (Bould et. al., 2014).

nodes.title: How to Achieve Maslow's Self-Actualization (Daniel Elesin)
nodes.description: In this short text, I explain how to achieve self-actualization from Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs, and the characteristics of individuals who have achieved self-actualization.

typeData.textContent:
We learned about Maslowâ€™s Hierarchy of Needs, however, we did not learn how to achieve the highest need, self-actualization.

In Maslowâ€™s Hierarchy of Needs, Maslow asserted that there are five fundamental needs that all of humankind requires: physiological, security, social, esteem, and self-actualization. According to Maslow, an individual must achieve the lower-level needs before they can achieve the higher-level needs. For instance, a personâ€™s physiological needs must be met before their security needs are met.

At the top of Maslowâ€™s Hierarchy of Needs is self-actualization, when an individual realizes their full potential and becomes the best version of themselves.

In his paper, â€œSelf-Actualizing People: a Study of Psychological Healthâ€, Maslow explores 13 characteristics common to individuals who have achieved self-actualization. Typically, self-actualized people tend to live independently, are comfortable with the unknown, accept themselves and others for who they are, have a sense of reality and truth, have a firm value system, enjoy meaningful friendships, are spontaneous, are kind and accepting, are creative, focus on the bigger picture rather than their own life, desire privacy, are intrinsically motivated, appreciate joyful, peaceful moments, and have an increased identification with others.

To achieve self-actualization, Maslow presents 8 suggestions in his book, "The Farther Reaches of Human Nature." The first suggestion is to live life in the moment. Next, Maslow recommends that individuals should pay attention to how they choose, considering life is significantly dependent on the choices made. Thirdly, Maslow advises that people should let their true selves emerge, and should not be influenced by the world. His fourth suggestion is to be honest in all situations. Individuals should take responsibility for their actions. Maslowâ€™s fifth piece of advice is similar to his third suggestion: people should listen to themselves as they embark on their unique journeys through life. His sixth recommendation explores the idea that hard work is the key to unlocking oneâ€™s full potential. Next, Maslow advises individuals to set up conditions for peak experiences. Maslowâ€™s eighth and final suggestion regards psychopathologies, and the importance of understanding dislikes to ensure that unpleasantness does not end up controlling oneâ€™s life. 

Although achieving self-actualization is a journey that can take many years to accomplish, the end results are fulfilling, making it a journey worth taking.

Sources: 
1) https://www.psychologytoday.com/ca/blog/moral-landscapes/201802/how-get-the-path-self-actualization
2) https://scottjeffrey.com/self-actualization/

nodes.title: Risk Factors for Eating Disorders (Teresa Liao)

typeData.textContent:
Eating disorders are mental illnesses recognised by the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5). These conditions are complex and are still being studied today. Researchers generally agree that eating disorders arises from some combination of biological, psychological, and socio-cultural factors. Anyone can develop an eating disorder but having more risk factors increases a personâ€™s likelihood of developing an eating disorder.


Biological Factors

-Family History of Eating Disorders (Bulik, Sullivan, & Kendler, 2003; Strober, 2000).

-Type 1 Diabetes (Jones et. al., 2000).

Eating disorders in diabetic subjects are associated with the omission of insulin. Initiation of insulin treatment is often accompanied by weight gain.


Psychological Factors

-Childhood Obsessive Compulsive Personality Traits.

These traits include perfectionism, inflexibility, excessive doubt and cautiousness, and drive for order and symmetry (Anderluh et. al., 2003).

-Traumatic Experiences.

These can include but are not limited to physical, sexual, and/or emotional abuse, neglect, and victimization. From research data, basically â€œany experience that can produce PTSD, partial PTSD, or any form of clinically significant anxietyâ€ (Brewerton, 2007, p. 287).

-Depression and Anxiety.

There are studies that support that eating disorders are sequela of depression and anxiety disorders, but it is also likely that depression, anxiety, and eating disorders share some etiological factors (Brownell, & Walsh, 2018).

-High Neurotic Personality and Low Self-Esteem (Cervera et al., 2003).

Neuroticism is a personality trait that consist of the tendency be in negative or anxious emotional state. People with neurotic personality also tend be in more depressive mood.


Socio-Cultural Factors

-Media Portrayal of Ideal Body (Lawrie, Sullivan, Davies, & Hill, 2006).

-Participation in Sports that Emphasis Body Shape or Leanness (Durme, Goossens, & Braet, 2012; Kong & Harris, 2014).

-Teasing or Bullying.

-Abusive Environment.


Other Factors

-Having Parents with Bipolar Affective Disorder, Personality Disorder, Anxiety, or Depression. 

Research shows that there is a correlation between parents with mental illnesses and their offspring developing eating disorders, but it is still unclear whether the eating disorder arises from genetics or the environment or a combination of both (Bould et. al., 2014).


References

Anderluh, M. B., Tchanturia, K., Rabe-Hesketh, S., & Treasure, J. (2003). Childhood Obsessive Compulsive Personality Traits in Adult Women With Eating Disorders: Defining a Broader Eating Disorder Phenotype. American Journal of Psychiatry, 160(2), 242-247. doi:10.1176/appi.ajp.160.2.242

Bould, H., Koupil, I., Dalman, C., Destavola, B., Lewis, G., & Magnusson, C. (2014). Parental mental illness and eating disorders in offspring. International Journal of Eating 	Disorders, 48(4), 383-391. doi:10.1002/eat.22325

Brewerton, T. (2007). Eating Disorders, Trauma, and Comorbidity: Focus on PTSD. Eating disorders, 15, 285-304. Doi:10.1080/10640260701454311.

Brownell, K. D., & Walsh, B. T. (2018). Eating disorders and obesity: A comprehensive handbook. New York, NY: The Guilford Press.

Bulik, C. M., Sullivan, P. F., & Kendler, K. S. (2003). Genetic and environmental contributions to obesity and binge eating. International Journal of Eating Disorders, 33(3), 293-298. doi:10.1002/eat.10140

Cervera, S., Lahortiga, F., MartÃ­nez-GonzÃ¡lez, M. A., Gual, P., Irala-EstÃ©vez, J. D., & Alonso, Y (2003). Neuroticism and low self-esteem as risk factors for incident eating disorders in a prospective cohort study. International Journal of Eating Disorders, 33(3), 271-280. doi:10.1002/eat.10147

Kong, P., & Harris, L. M. (2014). The Sporting Body: Body Image and Eating Disorder Symptomatology Among Female Athletes from Leanness Focused and Nonleanness Focused Sports. The Journal of Psychology, 149(2), 141-160. doi:10.1080/00223980.2013.846291
